lines.text:
[reading the label]
Not more than 40 percent alcohol... um hmm... I thought so.
Why the idea! 40. Well, that's probably to keep the iron from rusting.
I thought all American women were restless and dissatisfied.
But, you've never been to America.
No. But, I've met a lot of your country women on the continent.
Well, that accounts for it. Our happy women stay home.
You didn't.
What's he doing in Philadelphia?
Who?
Don.
Oh, yes, Philadelphia. Now, he's all right. I don't know. What's anybody do down there.
If Don's all right, nothing else matters.
Well, he, eh, isn't exactly all right. You see, there was some oats.
Oats?
Well, some wild oats.
Oh, Bill you're a mess!
All right, then, there's a girl.
A girl?
Don's gone haywire over a girl.
Believe me, she's bad medicine. One of those blondes - with a mother. They hunt together. What the gal shoots down, Mama drags home.
A wife should stick to her husband. If she doesn't, some other woman will!

[Talking to Nancy]
All men are like that. You marry 'em. You put 'em in cages. You lock 'em up every night and you say "Oh, see my nice tame husband." But, you just leave them for a little while and you see what happens?
Well, what does happen?
Peggy Preston. And your nice tame husband isn't tame anymore. He's wild! And you either get him back in the cage or you lose him.

[laughing]
Oh, Don, don't be early Victorian. Divorce does happen. It happened to practically all of our friends, it's not surprising it should happen to us.
I know; but, I didn't think you'd take it like this.

Oh, I know, you expected me to cry my eyes out and make a scene. Well, I'm sorry to disappoint you. But, you see, modern women don't act like that. We say, "Oh, our husband wants to go - does he. Very well, then, let him. Maybe next time we'll have better luck and get a really good one."
Tell me, what's this new - sweetie of yours like?
You know, you look exactly like a bad little boy caught stealing jam.
It's mother's "rubbing" alcohol.
Well, I know what my first job as an honest, married woman will be. I'll throw out everything in this room and get something modern!
Well, how 'bout meeting me, as long as it's a family party? I'm Bill Ross, Don's partner.
Oh, I know you. You always ran like a rabbit every time Don and I crossed your trail in town.
Well, I'll tell ya, I'm a two-way man. I can run from women and toward women.
It's so nice and modern to be - modern and not care who's husband belongs to who.
I like the country. Don't you like the country, Mr. Ross?
Yes, when I'm in the city.
Aren't you having tea Mr. Ross?
I never touch it. My doctor tells me it's poison!
Really?
I'll get you some.
I'm not trying to be funny. I just don't believe in marriage, that's all. Have you ever been married Mrs. Preston?
Why, Bill! Of course she has.
Oh, of course! I don't know what I could've been thinking of?
Oh, Mr. Ross, you're such an old tease!
Yes, I am sort of a tease.
I suppose one could like one's husband's wife even if one didn't like one's husband.
Why does everyone look so surprised? Is it so extraordinary that I should inspire love and devotion in some manly breast?
I was born under Venus, myself. Well, that is, in a matter of speaking.
So was I.
[With a wink and a grin]
What I know about you!
Oh, my, naughty, naughty, naughty.
You really shouldn't leave me alone with Mrs. Gibson. She puts wicked ideas into my head.
Isn't he the perfect husband. No matter what you do, my dear, he'll always believe in you.
You know, I'm a bit befuddled.
I don't see why you should care what I do.
I don't care a hang what you do! It's Peggy I'm thinking of.
Oh, that pure little flower!
Perhaps, now, there'll be a little chance for me.
Oh, it's sweet of you to want me.
But, you're still the lady who loves her husband?
Aren't women fools!

[Looking out the window at Don]
I know who is a fool.
Pretty little thing, Mrs. Gibson. I met her on the boat coming over.
Oh! I thought that *you* were her own private property.
No, dear me, no. I'm nobody's private property. I'm just a canary without a cage. And you?
Just a cage without a canary.
My baby mustn't leave herself open to wagging tongues!
Well, I still insist you cannot teach a woman anything!
You think we're too stupid to learn?
No, too clever.

[At the bridge table]
Don plays a beautiful game.
Very comforting - when you lose the rubber!
You know, I enjoy an early morning ride myself. It's a - great appetizer.
All women are alike.
All women are vampires.
I want you to get rid of Peggy and give Nancy of square deal.
Am I to understand that you're suggesting that I devote myself in the future - to your wife?
You may be right. As a matter of fact, I'm not at all sure that you're wrong. You may be right. And then again, you may be wrong.
When you really love somebody, you want them to be happy - no matter what it costs.
I've always been a very weak character.
You can't ever lose a man who really loves you and you can't hold one who doesn't.
